alert.note: Alert for Greenville; Pickens (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Flood Advisory issued August 29 at 12:44AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 630 AM EDT THIS MORNING... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...A portion of upstate South Carolina, including the following counties, Greenville and Pickens. * WHEN...Until 630 AM EDT. * IMPACTS...Nuisance flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to streams and other poor-drainage areas, including farmland, parks, greenways, boat-access areas, golf courses, underpasses, and parking lots. Isolated, shallow flows over roadways is possible. A few flood-prone, low-water crossings may become impassible. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1235 AM EDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing torrential rainfall from Table Rock State Park to Dacusville to Marietta, with widespread 2-3 inches across the Advisory area occurring within the past 60-90 minutes. The heaviest rainfall is departing the area, but excessive runoff is just beginning, resulting in rapid rises on small streams. Isolated areas of nuisance to Minor flooding are likely over the next few hours. Areas of greatest concern are along tributaries that feed the South Saluda River below Table Rock Reservoir, including along Beaverdam Creek near Dacusville Rd (SC 186), Carpenter Creek near Dacusville Hwy (SC 135) and Shoals Creek Church Rd, and the Middle Saluda River near N River Rd. - Another 0.5 to 1 inch of rainfall is possible over the next 30-60 minutes as isolated thunderstorms continue over the area before finally departing. However. additional heavy rainfall is possible later tonight. Given saturated soils, any new periods of heavy rainfall may cause new flood concerns to develop quickly. A Flash Flood Warning may be issued. Please stay weather aware and be prepared to seek higher ground if you are in an area vulnerable to flooding. - Some locations that may experience flooding include... Berea, Travelers Rest, Slater-Marietta, Pleasant Ridge State Park, Caesars Head State Park, Table Rock State Park, Paris Mountain State Park, Dacusville, Cleveland and Pumpkintown. - Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. It is important to know where you are relative to streams, rivers, or creeks which can become killers in heavy rains. Campers and hikers should avoid streams or creeks.
